ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned elementary Italian.
Better understanding and comprehension on the Italian language
italian grammar / basics, learn conversational italian
I developed my Italian skills
I continued to develop my ability to speak, write, and read in italian. I developed additional grammatical structures and rules, and learned how to use these in everyday conversation.
Continued to learn grammatical concepts including new tenses and moods. Practiced speaking, writing, and reading skills with a strong emphasis on reading comprehension compared to ITAL 110.
better fluidity in speaking italian

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course moves way too quickly to grasp content.

Strengths: the daily class really forces you to practice and keep up with the work which was very helpful since the class moved pretty quickly. Weaknesses: I thought that it was a bit too much homework especially since we would have to complete activities, watch or read videos / books, write temas, and read the pages for the next class almost every day.
I thought this courses biggest strength was its organization. Its really nice when courses follow a syllabus really closely. Also, Giacomo was really understanding, and a good professor.
this class is so much fun! I really felt like I learned italian well and I always looked forward to class
It was a great progression from 110 - the pace was good and I feel a much more capable speaker

This course is engaging, and my section in particular benefitted from an interesting curriculum that made the best of the virtual setting. Unfortunately, being virtual is one of the biggest setbacks as it hampers our ability to converse freely and naturally as we would in person.

Strengths: Daily classes and weekly essay assignments result in a high level of engagement that facilitate language learning.
Weaknesses: None
The class was well structured but Canvas was not used enough: we didnt have any grades posted on there and only received then via Canvas messages.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think learning languages is hard enough virtually, so having it move so quickly on Zoom was extremely difficult to navigate.
The virtual seminar format was really helpful because you still had to participate and pay attention.
The zoom meetings were engaging and enjoyable
Changing the homework to accomodate the virtual aspect of the course, and making the exams easy to take remotely made this class much less of a burden than it could have been.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend only if the student is interested in Italian. Not to a random student.

Yes, I love Italian at Yale. It is a fun and great class taught by people who really love Italian language and culture. I am sure that other language classes also have a bit of a workload, but this was still a good low-stress environment to learn a new language in.
Absolutely. Learning Italian is a really wonderful experience, and Id recommend it to anyone.
Yes
yes!!! this is a great class especially if you need to take a language
Absolutely- Italian is a great language and the Italian department have created a really good course here.
Yes, as L2 is where you begin to really take a cultural dive into Italian life, and get to seriously discuss music and art, as well as have a safe space to learn to read more fluently.
I would highly recommend this course to another student. As you delve into more advanced grammatical concepts, your scope of understanding will increase exponentially.
yes, learning italian has been fun and it's an engaging course

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Small group discussions every session
Supplemental learning through VHL software, access to textbook and grammar exercises.
